item.title: Ukraine sees an 'extremely strange' double standard after U.S. and allies help defend Israel
item.dc:creator: Daryna Mayer and Mithil Aggarwal and The Associated Press
item.description: Ukraine sees a double standard in U.S. and allies helping Israel shoot down the Iran attack while it waits for new support against Russian attacks.

media:content.media:text: Aftermath of a Russian missile strike in Chernihiv
media:content.media:description: Rescuers work at the site of a destroyed building after a Russian strike in Chernihiv, Ukraine on April 17, 2024.

media:content.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Office via AP
media:content.media:text: President Zelenskyy visits the frontlines
media:content.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has pleaded with Western countries to provide Ukraine with more support.

media:content.media:text: People take shelter inside a metro station during a Russian missile strike in Kyiv
media:content.media:description: People take shelter inside a metro station during an air alert in Kyiv on Wednesday.

item.title: Russian poetry prize bans entries from transgender people
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: A Russian poetry competition has banned transgender people from submitting entries this year, in what it says is an effort to protect traditional values.

media:content.media:text: A demonstrator holds a poster depicting Russian President Vladimir Putin with make-up during a protest
media:content.media:description: A protest against homophobia and repression against gays in Russia outside the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation in Madrid in 2013.

item.title: Doctors fear for their lives while scraping for basic medical supplies in Haiti
item.dc:creator: Fredlyn Pierre Louis
item.description: The escalation of gang violence in Haiti’s capital, Port-au-Prince, has prompted hospitals to close, caused a shortage of medical supplies and forced medical workers to suspend urgent assistance for Haitians.

media:content.media:text: People wait to be treated by health workers at a mobile health clinic organized by UNICEF and Medecins du Monde for people displaced by gang violence in Port-au-Prince on March 26, 2024.
media:content.media:description: People wait to be treated by health workers at a mobile health clinic organized by UNICEF and Medecins du Monde for people displaced by gang violence in Port-au-Prince on March 26.

media:content.media:text: Haitian police stand guard on a street corner amid gang violence in Port-au-Prince on April 8,2024.
media:content.media:description: Haitian police stand guard on a street corner amid gang violence in Port-au-Prince on April 8.

media:content.media:text: People take cover from gunfire during clashes between police and gangs near the National Palace in Port-au-Prince on April 8, 2024.
media:content.media:description: People take cover from gunfire during clashes between police and gangs near the National Palace in Port-au-Prince on April 8.

item.title: USC decision to cancel Muslim valedictorian's speech further inflames tensions on campus
item.dc:creator: Alicia Victoria Lozano
item.description: University of Southern California students said their hopes were dashed this week when the school canceled Muslim student Asna Tabassum 's commencement address.

media:content.media:text: A student walks on campus
media:content.media:description: Students on campus at the University of Southern California (USC) in Los Angeles, on April 16, 2024.

media:content.media:text: portrait usc valedictorian speech change
media:content.media:description: Asna Tabassum, a graduating senior, on the USC campus, on Tuesday.

item.title: Columbia University president grilled about campus antisemitism at congressional hearing
item.dc:creator: Emi Tuyetnhi Tran and Kyle Stewart
item.description: Columbia University’s President Nemat “Minouche” Shafik faced questions from House Republicans on her handling of antisemitism on campus after the Oct. 7 attack.

media:content.media:text: Nemat Shafik
media:content.media:description: Minouche Shafik, president of Columbia University, testifies during the House Education and the Workforce Committee on April 17, 2024.

item.title: Columbia University's president will testify in Congress on college conflicts over Israel-Hamas war
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Columbia University’s president is set answer questions on antisemitism and the school’s response to conflicts on campus over the Israel-Hamas war.

media:content.media:text: Bank Of England Governor Mark Carney Presents The Quarterly Inflation Report At A News Conference
media:content.media:description: Ahead of the hearing, Columbia University President Nemat Shafik wrote an op-ed addressing free speech and campus safety.

item.title: Sen. Tom Cotton doubles down on comments urging people to 'forcibly remove' protesters blocking traffic
item.dc:creator: Kate Santaliz and Zoë Richards
item.description: Sen. Tom Cotton on Tuesday doubled down on comments urging people delayed by traffic stemming from pro-Palestinian demonstrations to "forcibly remove" some protesters who are blocking streets.

media:content.media:text: Senator Tom Cotton
media:content.media:description: Sen. Tom Cotton, R-Ark., at a hearing in Washington on March 11.

item.title: Class destroyed: A look at what has become of Gaza's revered universities
item.dc:creator: Chantal Da Silva and Yasmine Salam and Matthew Mulligan and Bianca Britton
item.description: Built over decades, Gaza’s universities embodied the ambitions of young Palestinians. In weeks, the Israeli military destroyed them.

item.title: She secretly educated herself to escape Afghanistan. Now, she's working to help women still there
item.dc:creator: Maya Eaglin
item.description: Sola Mahfouz stopped going to school in 2007 when she was an 11-year-old living in Afghanistan.

item.title: Meet the families who've taken children as young as 2 to Everest Base Camp
item.dc:creator: Aria Bendix
item.description: A handful of families have taken children as young as 2 years old to Mount Everest Base Camp in recent years. Three of them describe the experience.

media:content.media:text: Hazel Matulis at Everest Base Camp in 2022.
media:content.media:description: Hazel Matulis at Everest Base Camp in 2022.

media:content.media:text: Dimple Laddha took her daughter, Arishka, last year when Arishka was just 6 years old.

media:content.media:text: Chris and Cindy Matulis with their kids at Everest Base Camp in 2022.

item.title: Looking for leads, not love: Job seekers in China turn Tinder into a networking tool
item.dc:creator: Larissa Gao and Helen Chen
item.description: Young people in China facing an increasingly tough labor market are turning to an unlikely place for help in their job searches: Tinder.

media:content.media:text: Photo Illustration: A man's Tinder profile reads "Looking for Full-tim employment"
media:content.media:description: Some young people in China see Tinder as a way to find potential job leads.

media:content.media:text: China Youth Unemployment
media:content.media:description: University students at a job fair in Wuhan, China, in March.

item.title: Inside Iran's arsenal after attack on Israel
item.description: Iran launched more than 300 retaliatory drones and missiles on Israel in response to Israel's suspected attack on its consulate in Syria. NBC News' Gadi Schwartz breaks down what we know about Iran's weaponry.

media:content.media:title: Inside Iran's arsenal after attack on Israel
media:content.media:description: Iran launched more than 300 retaliatory drones and missiles on Israel in response to Israel's suspected attack on its consulate in Syria. NBC News' Gadi Schwartz breaks down what we know about Iran's weaponry.

item.title: Excitement grows in Paris with 100 days to the Olympics
item.description: With just 100 days to go until the 2024 Olympics begin in Paris, preparations are full speed ahead in the city of light. NBC's Keir Simmons shares a preview.

media:content.media:title: Excitement grows in Paris with 100 days to the Olympics
media:content.media:description: With just 100 days to go until the 2024 Olympics begin in Paris, preparations are full speed ahead in the city of light. NBC's Keir Simmons shares a preview.

item.title: Unprecedented flooding soaks Dubai
item.description: A massive storm that flooded roads and closed the airport in Dubai also killed at least 18 people in neighboring Oman.

media:content.media:title: Unprecedented flooding soaks Dubai
media:content.media:description: A massive storm that flooded roads and closed the airport in Dubai also killed at least 18 people in neighboring Oman.

item.title: Indonesian officials warn of tsunami after volcano erupts
item.description: At least 11,000 people were forced to evacuate after a volcano erupted in Indonesia. The government is encouraging residents to leave with fears that part of the volcano could break off into the ocean and trigger a tsunami.

media:content.media:title: Indonesian officials warn of tsunami after volcano erupts
media:content.media:description: At least 11,000 people were forced to evacuate after a volcano erupted in Indonesia. The government is encouraging residents to leave with fears that part of the volcano could break off into the ocean and trigger a tsunami.

item.title: India kicks off the world’s largest elections this week. Here’s what you need to know
item.dc:creator: Charmaine Jacob, CNBC and Joanna Tan, CNBC
item.description: Indians head to the polls Friday in the world’s largest democratic election, as almost a billion voters decide whether to re-elect Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

media:content.media:text: Indians head to the polls on Friday in what will be the world’s largest democratic election, as close to one billion voters pick their next government and decide whether to hand Prime Minister Narendra Modi a third term in office.
media:content.media:description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi at an election campaign event in Chennai on April 9.

item.title: China slams U.S. probe into its shipbuilding industry, calling it a ‘mistake on top of a mistake’
item.dc:creator: Sheila Chiang, CNBC
item.description: China said it “firmly opposes” the U.S. investigation into its maritime, logistics and shipbuilding industries, calling it a “mistake on top of a mistake.”

media:content.media:text: Ship Repair Underway In Guangzhou's Shipyard
media:content.media:description: Workers hoist a propeller at a COSCO shipyard in Guangzhou, China, last month.

item.title: Woman wheels corpse into Brazil bank to sign for loan
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: A woman in Brazil brought a 68-year-old man in a wheelchair into a bank branch and tried to get him to sign for a loan, but he had been dead for hours, Brazilian police said on Wednesday.

media:content.media:text: Brazilian reais cash bills and flag of Brazil
media:content.media:description: Brazilian reais

item.title: Tsunami alert issued after volcano erupts in Indonesia, with thousands told to evacuate
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Indonesian authorities issued a tsunami alert Wednesday amid ongoing eruptions of the Ruang volcano, which have sent ash thousands of feet into the air.

media:content.media:credit: Center for Volcanology and Geological Hazard Mitigation
media:content.media:text: Mount Ruang spews hot lava and smoke
media:content.media:description: Mount Ruang spews hot lava and smoke on the northern side of Sulawesi island in Indonesia on April 17, 2024.

item.title: UAE government says cloud seeding didn’t take place before Dubai floods
item.dc:creator: Joan Muwahed, CNBC
item.description: A United Arab Emirates government task force said it had not carried out cloud seeding missions in the run-up to the heavy storms that caused flooding in Dubai.

media:content.media:text: Aftermath following floods caused by heavy rains in Dubai
media:content.media:description: A person walks Wednesday in floodwater caused by heavy rain in Dubai.

item.title: $14.5M gold heist from Toronto airport results in charges for airline employee, 8 others
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Police said nine people are facing charges in what authorities are calling the biggest gold theft in Canadian history from Toronto’s Pearson International airport a year ago.

media:content.media:text: Stacked gold bars

item.title: U.S. Navy flies aircraft through the Taiwan Strait a day after U.S.-China defense chiefs hold rare talks
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: The U.S. 7th Fleet said a Navy P-8A Poseidon flew through the Taiwan Strait on Wednesday, a day after U.S. and Chinese defense chiefs held their first talks since November 2022 in an effort to reduce regional tensions.

media:content.media:text: A U.S. Navy P-8A Poseidon
media:content.media:description: A U.S. Navy P-8A Poseidon flies over the Philippine Sea on Feb. 24, 2023.

item.title: Georgia’s parliament approves law on ‘foreign agents’ in first reading
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Georgia’s parliament on Wednesday approved the first reading of a bill on “foreign agents” that has provoked several days of protests by critics who see it as authoritarian and Russian-inspired, Georgian media reported.

media:content.media:text: Georgia's parliament was poised to advance on April 17, 2024 with a controversial "foreign influence" law that has sparked mass street protests over concerns it would undermine Tbilisi's European aspirations.
media:content.media:description: A protester holds a Georgian flag during a demonstration outside the parliament building in Tbilisi on Wednesday.

media:content.media:text: Demonstrators gather against proposed foreign agent bill in Georgia's Tbilisi
media:content.media:description: Demonstrators protest the reintroduction of the "foreign agents" bill in Tbilisi on Tuesday night.

item.title: A painting of Winston Churchill by an artist whose work he hated is up for auction
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: LONDON — A portrait of Winston Churchill by an artist whose work the British leader loathed went on display Tuesday at Churchill’s birthplace ahead of an auction in June.

media:content.media:text: A portrait of Winston Churchill painted by Graham Sutherland in 1954, on view at Blenheim Palace, Woodstock, England
media:content.media:description: A portrait of Winston Churchill painted by Graham Sutherland in 1954 at Blenheim Palace in Woodstock, England, on Tuesday.

item.title: LeBron James, Stephen Curry and more NBA stars will represent Team USA in the 2024 Olympics
item.dc:creator: Drew Weisholtz, TODAY
item.description: Time will tell if it’s another Dream Team, but the roster for the United States men’s basketball team at the upcoming 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris was officially revealed Wednesday on "TODAY."

media:content.media:text: Kevin Durant (left) and LeBron James.
media:content.media:description: Kevin Durant (left) and LeBron James celebrate after defeating Spain in the gold medal game at the Summer Olympics in London on Aug. 12, 2012
